Yadav * Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai 400 019, India Department of Chemical Engineering Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg Matunga Mumbai 400 019 India Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga Mumbai-400 019, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Octahedral molecular sieve (OMS-2) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method and modified by the impregnation of different metals to give M/OMS-2 catalysts (where M = V, Cr, Fe, Co, and Mo). All these catalysts were tested in the oxidation of o-cresol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (or salicylaldehyde, SAL). Among all M/OMS-2 catalysts, 5% Co/OMS-2 was found to be the most active catalyst for selective oxidation of o-cresol to SAL. Effect of several oxygen sources such as air, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), molecular oxygen (O2), and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was studied for the oxidation of o-cresol. There was a complete conversion of o-cresol with 98% yield of SAL at 5 atm O2 pressure and 80 °C in 2 h. Additionally, the catalysts (virgin as well as reused forms) were characterized by FESEM, EDS, HR-TEM, XRD, CO2-TPD, TPR, Raman Spectra, BET surface area analysis, XPS, and DSC-TGA. The reaction kinetic model was developed using Mars van Krevelen mechanism. The catalyst was found to be inexpensive, robust, active, and showed very good reusability of 4 cycles, which makes it an attractive choice for o-cresol oxidation to SAL. The atom economy of the oxidation process is 98.15%. Thus, this process is an example of the synthesis of a vital chemical entity, salicylaldehyde, at mild reaction condition by a novel clean and green route. SAL is a well-known chemical intermediate and represents a major platform molecule for a variety of precursors and applications: in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, plastics, agrochemicals, petrochemicals, perfumes, and electroplating intermediates, etc. [3]. Currently, SAL and its derivatives continue to attract substantial interest in other applications such as antimicrobial and antifungal formulations [4,5], metal complexes, Schiff bases [6], and crosslinkers [7]. Several traditional methods have been employed for the synthesis of SAL such as Reimer–Tiemann reaction [8], where the yield of SAL was <40%. Secondly, chlorination of methyl group of o-cresol and saponification of the subsequent dichloromethyl group produces SAL [9]. In the well-known Duff reaction, phenol is reacted with paraformaldehyde in the presence of magnesium chloride, which leads to SAL [10]. However, the aforesaid methods have many drawbacks such as the use of homogeneous catalysts, necessity of a huge quantity of NaOH, and generation of toxic wastes, etc. [1]. Only a few reports have been published on the oxidation of o-cresol and selective synthesis of SAL. A single-step o-cresol oxidation was done using CuCo/C catalyst and pyridine as an additive at 90 °C and 6 atm O2 pressure, which resulted in 73.8% conversion and 57.3% selectivity to SAL [1]. Oxidation of p/o-cresol to p/o-hydroxybenxzaldehyde was reported using metalloporphyrins as catalyst. Iron porphyrins (T(p−OCH3)PPFeCl) and NaOH were used at 70 °C and atmospheric O2 pressure to yield 11.5% SAL at 45.8% conversion of o-cresol [2]. Oxidation of cresol isomers was also reported in the presence of ozone over γ -Al2O3 and SiO2 [11]. In this case, the maximum value for the conversion of o-cresol was 38.9 and 45.7% in 5 h on γ -Al2O3 and SiO2, respectively, and the byproducts were tolyl acetate, di-hydroxytoluene, and diethyl maleate. CoOx@CN (carbon nanotube) catalyst was used for selective oxidation of substituted p-cresols to respective p-hydroxybenzaldehydes [12]. The open literature represents numerous ways of synthesis of SAL; nevertheless, a daunting task has always been to achieve high yield and conversion at mild reaction conditions using a green catalytic process. Different mesoporous catalysts have been reported for oxidation processes. A periodic mesoporous organosilica (PMO) catalyst, Cu@Al/Si-PMO-TU was effectively used for complete oxidation of dibenzothiophene [13] in a green oxidation process. Mesoporous silica such as SBA-15 supported catalyst effectively oxidized benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with 95% selectivity [14]. Takovite-aluminosilicate composite was studied as a catalyst for hydrocarbon oxidation [15]. Mesoporous titanium silicates were used for toluene oxidation which gave 100% selectivity to benzaldehyde [16]. Oxides such as ZrO2 and Al2O3 supported undecamolybdophosphate catalysts were reported for green oxidation of alcohols and alkenes [17]. Iron oxide supported on aluminosilicate was used extensively for oxidation of numerous alcohols to the respective carbonyl compounds in the presence of hydrogen peroxide [18]. Capsule membrane catalysis (CM-PTC) was studied both by theory and experiment [19] for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with H2O2 as oxidant whereas a combination of heteropolyacids and phase transfer catalysts was studied for the same system [20]. Octahedral molecular sieve (OMS-2) consists a porous solid consisting of corner and edge shared by MnO6 octahedra structure of 2 × 2 tunnel with K+ for balancing the charge (Fig. 1 ) [19,21]. OMS-2 is environmentally benign [22] and widely used in diverse applications including electrochemistry, redox catalysts [23], batteries and supercapacitors [24], sensors [25], etc. OMS-2 gained considerable recognition as a prominent catalyst in selective oxidation of different valuable alcohols such as cinnamyl alcohol, secondary alcohols, 1-octanol, etc. to their respective aldehydes [26–29]. Multi-valent Mn is widely used in many redox reactions and of great importance due to its ability to act as an electron transporter [2,30]. Furthermore, OMS-2 has a distinct advantage over aluminosilicate molecular sieves because of its tendency to alter valence state and mobility of oxygen ions [31]. The catalytic oxidation by OMS-2 and metal-impregnated OMS-2 is found to proceed by Mars–van Krevelen mechanism, where the oxygen from the surface lattice and gas-phase O2 play an important part [29]. The foregoing shows that finding a suitable oxidation catalyst with high activity and selectivity without over-oxidation at low temperature is most challenging. Therefore, in the present work, the selective oxidation of o-cresol was targeted using O2 and OMS-2 in combination with cheap transition metals: Cr, V, Fe, Co, Mo, etc. Different oxygen sources such as air, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were also studied for their efficacy in the oxidation of o-cresol. The catalyst characterization, of both virgin and reused, was performed using CO2–TPD, FTIR, Raman, BET surface area, XRD, XPS, FESEM, EDS, HR-TEM, DSC-TGA, and TPR. A kinetic model was established using Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. There is no published information on the bifunctional Co/OMS-2 catalyst, which is used for selective o-cresol oxidation to SAL. The present work was compared with the reported literature (Table 1 ). The compared results of conversion of o-cresol and selectivity of salicyl aldehyde (SAL) indicated the superiority of the present work than that of the literature. It will be discussed later. 2 Methodology 2.1 Materials All necessary chemicals were procured from reputed traders: o-cresol, potassium permanganate, manganese sulfate hydrate, and methanol (HPLC grade) (Thomas Baker, Mumbai, India); acetonitrile, isopropyl alcohol (IPA), dimethylformamide (DMF), and 1, 4 dioxane (AVRA synthesis Pvt. Ltd., Hyderabad, India); ferrous nitrate nonahydrate, cobaltous nitrate, ammonium metavanadate, oxalic acid, ammonium molybdate, chromium nitrate, H2O2, and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) (S D Fine Chemicals, Mumbai). O2 (purity of 99.9%) cylinder was procured from Rakhangi Gas Suppliers, Mumbai. 2.2 Catalyst preparation OMS-2 was prepared by the hydrothermal method, as reported by our lab, with a little modification (see SI) [32]. V/OMS-2 was prepared as per the method given in Yadav et al. [33]. Various M/OMS-2 catalysts (where M = Cr, V, Mo, Co, and Fe) were prepared by the impregnation method. In general, a sufficient quantity of OMS-2 support and distilled water was taken to which x wt. % of metal (M) (where x = 3%, 5%, 7%, and 9%) precursor solution was added dropwise for 3 h. Finally, water was evaporated in rotovac, the catalyst mass dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. 2.3 Reaction setup and analysis All experiments were carried out using an autoclave (50 mL) (Autoclave Engineers, USA). For the standard experiment, 0.0046 mol o-cresol and 0.25 g catalyst were added to the reactor, and O2 purged through the reactor. After achieving the desired temperature, it was pressurized with O2 at a chosen pressure. The samples were collected periodically and analyzed using HPLC (Agilent 1260 infinity) and CHEMSIL C18 column (4.6 mm I.D × 250 mm length × 5 μ m) and UV detector (239 nm). Acetonitrile and DI water (15:85) were employed with 1 mL/min flow rate as the mobile phase. The product was confirmed using GC–MS (Thermo Scientific) equipped with TG-5MS capillary column (Thermo Scientific Trace 1300 ISQ LT), (SI, Fig. S1). Furthermore, 1H and 13C NMR of SAL was done and discussed in SI (Figs S2 and S3) using Agilent NMR instrument. 2.4 Reaction schematic See Scheme 1 for oxidationn of o-cresol giving salicylaldehyde with water as a co-product. 3 Results and discussion Full characterization of all catalysts was done and the best catalyst 5% Co/OMS-2 studied in greater detail. 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties of catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption profile shows a type IV isotherm curve representing the mesoporous nature of the catalyst (Fig. 2 ). BET surface area analysis reveals a decrease in surface area and pore volume of 5% Co/OMS-2 than OMS-2, indicating that impregnated nanoparticles of Co were well dispersed over OMS-2 surface, and the pores occupied by it (Table 2 ). At a relative pressure ( p / p 0 ) of 0.8–1, a tapered slit porous shape adsorption curve was observed, which is the characteristic representation of rod-like fibers [34,35]. There was a negligible change in surface area and pore volume of both virgin and reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst indicating that catalyst structure was unaffected by surface disruption. 3.1.2 XRD The XRD patterns of cryptomelane-phase of OMS-2 catalyst were in good agreement with that of previous work [32]. The diffraction patterns with their respective phases are presented in Fig. 3 . The influence of addition of Co on the nature of OMS-2 was evaluated for 5 wt. % Co loading. It was observed that both oxide forms of cobalt, namely CoO and Co2O3, were present in the crystalline structure of the catalyst. Both 5% Co/OMS-2 and reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks of CoO phase (JCPDS #01-076-3830 (A)) which were located at 2θ value of 36.61 (111), 42.4 (020), 73.1 (311), 77.06 (2-22), respectively. Similarly, Co2O3 phase (JCPDS # 01-076-1802 (A)) was located at 2θ values corresponding to 19.2 (11-1), 31.2 (20-2), 65.2 (04-4), respectively (Fig. 3B and C). It was noted that some of the peaks of cobalt oxide were found overlapping with that of the cryptomelane phase. 3.1.3 CO2-TPD CO2-TPD study was done for measuring basic sites for all three materials, namely, OMS-2, virgin 5% Co/OMS-2, and reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalysts in the temperature range of 50−700 °C (Fig. 4 ). All catalysts show sharp peaks in between 65−200 °C, which imply the presence of weak basic sites. In the case of virgin 5% Co/OMS-2 as well as reused 5% Co/OMS-2, the peak intensity increased, reflecting increase in weak basic sites, which is also confirmed from Table 3 . The small humps at ∼300 °C and also at ∼500 °C suggest the presence of moderate and strong basic sites present on catalyst surface (Fig. 4B and C). Total basicity values for OMS-2, 5% Co/OMS-2, and reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalysts are presented in Table 3. 3.1.4 FTIR The FTIR spectra show the stretching and bending vibration of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). Since the framework structure of the catalyst is MnO2 based, OMS-2, virgin 5% Co/OMS-2, and reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalysts have all similar vibrations. The intense stretching and bending adsorption band of ∼1599 was due to the presence of adsorbed water inside the tunnels of OMS-2 cadge. All samples displayed signature dominant peaks at 711 and 660 cm−1 ascribed to Mn-O as well as Mn−O−Mn lattice vibration of MnO6 octahedra [36]. The broad stretching band at ∼3441 cm−1 is due to −OH groups [37] present in the samples. 3.1.5 Raman spectra Fig. 6 represents the Raman spectra of OMS-2 and 5% Co/OMS-2. The intense peak at 664 cm−1 indicates the presence of Mn3O4 in the OMS-2 [32,38]. Moreover, small bands at 325 and 374 cm−1 also display Mn3O4 phase in OMS-2, which is also in accordance with the literature value [39]. The broad peak in the region of 590−720 cm−1 and a small hump at 360 cm−1 (Fig. 6B) was reported for the presence of cobalt oxide species [40,41]. The interaction of Co and Mn might have resulted in the broad Raman spectra for 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst. 3.1.6 TPR TPR profile of 5% Co/OMS-2 includes two reductive signals of which the sharp peak was observed at 345 and the satellite peak at 398 °C (Fig. 7 ). As per the literature, Co2O3 reduction profile includes a peak below 300 °C and another at ∼500 °C [42]. Therefore, in agreement with this, the dominance of CoO was found to be greater. It could be so because Co2O3 phase might have reduced to CoO and further to Co metal. The peaks present at higher temperatures, 532 and 625 °C suggest that Co metal has excellent interaction with MnO2 of OMS-2 cage, which resulted in better catalyst activity and stability. 3.1.7 XPS The XPS measurement for 5% Co/OMS-2 with its elements Co (2p), Mn (2p, 3s), O (1s), K(2p) is given in Fig. 8 . The identified atoms with a description of their atomic concentration are shown in Table 4 . Co 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 were obtained at 777 and 793 eV (Fig. 9 ). The value is very near to the literature value for Co2+ state [42,43]. The shift in binding energy (B.E.) might have occurred due to a strong association with that of Mn of OMS-2. Moreover, the small peaks at 787 and 802.3 eV represent Co2+ oxidation state [44]. Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 peaks were observed at B.E. of 651 and 638 eV, respectively [45]. O1s spectra at 526.5 and 528.7 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen, and surface adsorbed oxygen, respectively [46,47]. 3.1.8 FESEM and EDS Fig. 10 represents FESEM of OMS-2 and virgin 5% Co/OMS-2. The samples show characteristic morphology of fibrous rod-like structures, with fibers in length between 1 and 1.5 μm (Fig. 10B). A remarkable change was observed after loading of Co such as aggregation and formation of clusters of the fibrous nanorods (Fig. 10C and D). However, there was no structural deformation of the catalyst (Fig. 10D). Table 5 shows the elemental composition of 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst, determined by EDS and it was found as-synthesized amount. The elemental mapping was done to observe the elemental dispersion of 5% OMS-2 catalyst over the surface. Fig. 11 represents the homogeneous dispersion of Mn, O, K, and Co over the nanorods. The atomic wt.% of Co was found to be 5.5%. 3.1.9 HR-TEM In agreement with FESEM, HR-TEM images of both OMS-2 and 5% Co/OMS-2 catalysts clearly demonstrate that the samples are composed of agglomerated nanorods (Fig. 12 ). The average diameter of the nanorod was found to be in the range of 10−12 nm. A close examination of MnO2 nanorods clearly showed the interlayer spacing of ∼4.6 A° (Fig. 12C). Interestingly, this value is in accordance with the literature [48]. The significant dispersion of Co over OMS-2 surface can be verified from Fig. 12E. Furthermore, the impregnated Co was well dispersed over the nanorods and hence it confirmed the uniform dispersion of Co (Fig. 12 E). The SAED pattern of samples demonstrates highly crystalline nature (Fig. 12 F).The average particle size of Co was ∼2.7 nm. 3.1.10 TGA-DSC Thermal properties of virgin 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst were studied; TGA-DSC pattern is illustrated in Fig. 13 . There was a trivial weight loss of ∼3%−4%, representing that the catalyst has good thermal stability. Minor weight loss in the range of 50−100 °C is attributed to physisorbed water molecules. The endothermic peak in the region of 600−700 °C indicated that there was no alteration in the MnO2 oxidation state. Since there was no decomposition peak after 700 °C, the catalyst was stable upto 800 °C. 3.2 Activity test Different catalysts were tested for their activity in o-cresol oxidation (Fig. 14 ). OMS-2 in the presence of O2 resulted in 25% conversion of o-cresol with the selectivity of SAL, salicylic acid (SAC), and salicyl alcohol (SA) as 42%, 27%, and 23%, respectively. Furthermore, the promotion of Fe, Cr, V, Mo, and Co resulted in varying selectivity to products (Fig. 14). The conversion of o-cresol was in the following order: 5% Co/OMS-2 (max.) > 5% Mo/OMS-2 > 5% Cr/OMS-2 > 5% V/OMS-2 > 5% Fe/OMS-2 > OMS-2. The selectivity to SAL was; 5% Co/OMS-2 (max.) > 5% Mo/OMS-2 > 5% V/OMS-2 > 5% Fe/OMS-2 > 5% Cr/OMS-2 > OMS-2 Since 5% Co/OMS-2 was proven to be the best, giving 99.5% conversion and 98% selectivity to SAL, it was chosen for further experimentation. The turn over frequency (TOF) of 5% Co/OMS-2 was calculated as 0.61 h−1 and found to be as per the literature [49] for OMS-2 based catalysts. Also, it indicated that 5% Co/OMS-2 is highly selective and produced SAL at mild reaction condition and without generation of waste. The comparison with previous work is given in Table 1 to illustrate its superiority. The reason why cobalt works as the best catalyst with OMS-2 are many. Transition metal catalysts in general act by two ways. First the metal center has very high positive charges and is very electronegative; it will attract the electrons forming bonds and in other parts of the molecule. This polarizes CC bonds and allows insertion of another group. The other effect is that the metal coordinates the molecules in a small area, greatly increasing the local concentration of reactants, speeding up the reaction. Co has a lower energy barrier for these transitions. The oxidation-reduction properties of cobalt lead to different valences of I, II or III and thus electrons can be easily transferred between these states, increasing rates of reactions at lower temperature which was the case in our studies and the characterization showed it. It was observed that both oxide forms of cobalt, namely CoO and Co2O3, were present in the crystalline structure of the catalyst and that some of the peaks of cobalt oxide were found overlapping with that of the cryptomelane phase of OMS-2 giving synergism (Section 3.1.2 XRD studies). Because of different valences cobalt has a great ability in accepting atoms from other molecules and forming complex molecules. Solid cobalt compounds have vacancies within their crystal lattice promoting catalysis and these vacancies are filled during oxidation by oxygen as reactant. In the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, lattice O is given to oxidize the substrate creating vacancies easily. Like cobalt, OMS-2 contains multivalent manganese ions (Mn3+ and Mn4+), has abundant pore structures, and exhibits mild acidity–basicity, strong ion exchange ability, and high thermal stability. All of these features render OMS-2 to exhibit good catalytic performance for oxidation. The combination of Co with OMS-2 works synergistically and the interaction of Co and Mn resulted in the broad Raman spectra for 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst. As explained before the XPS spectra showed that the shift in binding energy of Co2+ might have occurred due to a strong association with that of Mn of OMS-2. Moreover, the small peaks at 787 and 802.3 eV represents Co2+ oxidation state. Thus, there is higher activity of 5% Co/OMS-2 permitting greater mobility of the lattice oxygen. The characterization of the catalysts discussed before support the foregoing explanation adequately. 3.3 Optimization of various reaction parameters Effect of speed of agitation, rection time, and different solvents on conversion of o-cresol is discussed in detail in SI. 3.3.1 Effect of various oxygen sources When air was used, there was 100% conversion; however, it was found that only polymerized products were formed. This might have occurred due to poor solubility of oxygen from air as compared to molecular oxygen, H2O2 and TBHP. Secondly, there might be inhibition in regeneration of lattice oxygen for oxidation. As H2O2 is highly reactive and sensitive to temperature, the reaction was carried out at a slightly lower temperature (60 °C), giving only 20% conversion. Similarly, in the presence of TBHP, there was a complete conversion of o-cresol with selectivity to SAL, SAC, and other (polymerized) products as 72%, 7.5%, and 20.5%, respectively (Table 6 ). While molecular oxygen stands out to be a better source of oxidation, it also gave complete conversion and selectivity upto 98%. Hence, O2 was chosen in all further studies. 3.3.2 Effect of catalyst loading The effect of available active sites on the conversion of o-cresol was tested by varying the catalyst loading from 0.006 to 0.01 g/cm3 (Fig. 15 ). There was an increase in conversion of o-cresol with the respective loading of catalyst mass due to the proportional increase in active sites. Beyond 0.008 g/cm3 catalyst loading, there was no change in the conversion; hence, 0.008 g/cm3 was taken as the optimized quantity for further study. Fig. 16 shows initial rate of reaction vs. catalyst loading. It was observed that the initial rate was directly proportional to the number of active sites or catalyst loading. 3.3.3 Effect of metal loading Since Co/OMS-2 was the best catalyst for this reaction, different loadings of Co such as 3 wt.%, 5 wt.%, 7 wt.%, and 9 wt.% were studied for the oxidation of o-cresol (Fig. 17 ). Among all the loadings, 5% loading of Co/OMS-2 catalyst was the best, because with any additional increase in metal loading, there was no proportionate increase in conversion of o-cresol. There was no significant change in the selectivity of SAL until 7% of Co; however, at 9%, the selectivity of SAL was 85.5% and that of SAC increased upto 14.5% due to over-oxidation (Table 7 ). 3.3.4 Effect of O2 pressure Oxygen pressure was varied between 3 and 11 atm. At 5 atm, there was 98% selectivity to SAL (Fig. 18 ). Any further increase in pressure did not change the conversion. However, beyond 5 atm (at 7 and 9 atm) there was polymerization of o-cresol leading to the formation of di, tri, and tetramers of o-cresol, which was confirmed by GCMS analysis. Hence, all further reactions were done at 5 atm O2 pressure. 3.3.5 Effect of temperature The reaction was studied to understand the effect of temperature from 70 to 85 °C. With an increase in temperature, the rate of oxidation was found to increase. There was a complete conversion of o-cresol at 80 °C. However, beyond 85 °C there was a sharp decrease in the selectivity of SAL (Fig. 19 ). This was due to the formation of a mixture of polymerized products, which could not be detected by GCMS analysis. Therefore, 80 °C was selected as the optimized temperature for further studies. 3.4 Reusability experiments The catalyst reusability and stability was confirmed by two approaches as given below. The catalyst was reused by separating it from reaction mass after each use by filtration. It was then washed several times with solvent methanol, dried at 100 °C and, used for the next cycle. 1. The actual recovered quantity of the catalyst was used in the reusability studies which were conducted using less quantity of reaction volume by keeping the same concentration of o-cresol but keeping the same catalyst loading, w, in mass/volume (g/cm3). It ensured the same mole of reactants/mass of catalyst. We repeated four experiments for reuse without any catalyst make-up and conducted the reactions for 30 min by limiting the conversion to less than 30%. In all these cases the initial rates of reaction as well as conversion with time were measured periodically. These values were within ± 3 which confirmed the stability of the catalyst. Additionally, the values of textural properties and CO2-TPD of reused 5% Co/OMS-2 catalyst were nearly the same as those of fresh 5% Co/OMS-2. The characterization of virgin and reused catalyst after fourth cycle proved the stability of the catalyst. 2. The loss during this treatment was recovered by adding a fresh catalyst and maintaining the equal weight for every cycle. To make up the loss of catalyst, which is typically less than 2%, fresh catalyst was added to maintain the same catalyst loading (w) (g/cm3) by keeping the same volume of reactants, and the same mole of reactants/mass of catalyst. This approach was already followed for 4 recycles (Fig. 20 ). Again, the catalyst stability was confirmed through recharacterization of the catalyst including textural properties (Table 2). Both these approaches demonstrated that even after four cycles, there was hardly any change in the oxidation activity of the catalyst. Thus, the catalyst was found to maintain its fidelity. 3.5 Reaction mechanism and kinetics 5% Co/OMS-2 has metal sites (Sm) as well as weak basic sites (Sb), which aid in selective oxidation of o-cresol. Initial analysis suggested that the reaction follows the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [25], which involves the participation of oxygen from the surface lattice of M/OMS-2 in the reaction creating a vacancy followed by regeneration of surface oxygen, which was supplied through the oxygen source such as air or molecular oxygen or TBHP. o-Cresol adsorbs on Sb while oxygen adsorbs on Sm. This is followed by surface reaction, where the surface lattice oxygen of metal (Co) attacks on adjacent side chain methyl carbon to convert it into the aldehyde group, leaving behind oxygen-deficient Co ions. This oxygen deficient Co ions (of site Sm) are immediately replaced by oxygen and thus site is regenerated. Also, the formation of water results as shown in Scheme 2 . It is assumed in this mechanism that water is not adsorbed but released along with the product SAL. The activation energy for oxidation step was calculated from the Arrhenius plot and was found to be 14.7 kcal/mol (Fig. 22 ). 4 Conclusion In summary, selective oxidation of o-cresol was studied over various bi-functional M/OMS-2 catalysts (where M = V, Cr, Fe, Co, and Mo). Among all the catalysts 5% Co/OMS-2 nanorods, synthesized by the hydrothermal followed by the impregnation methods was the best catalyst giving complete conversion of o-cresol, and 98% yield of SAL at 80 °C and 5 atm O2 pressure. The reaction mechanism was developed based on Mars–van Krevelen mechanism. The activation energy for the oxidation step was 14.7 kcal/mol. Moreover, the facile preparation, robustness, high activity, selectivity and reusability make 5% Co/OMS-2 as a unique oxidation catalyst under mild conditions. TOF of 5% OMS-2 was found to be 0.61 h−1. The reaction shows 98.15% atom economy with reference to o-cresol without generation of any waste. High surface area, activity, selectivity and mobility of lattice oxygen defines 5% Co/OMS-2 nanorods to be excellent catalyst for o-cresol oxidation. There is a synergism of Co and OMS-2 for its superior performance over others considered in this reaction. An industrially important salicylaldehyde was synthesized by the entirely clean and green route. Author credit statement Both authors have contributed equally. The experiments were performed by D.S. coredata.dc:description: Octahedral molecular sieve (OMS-2) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method and modified by the impregnation of different metals to give M/OMS-2 catalysts (where M = V, Cr, Fe, Co, and Mo). All these catalysts were tested in the oxidation of o-cresol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (or salicylaldehyde, SAL). Among all M/OMS-2 catalysts, 5% Co/OMS-2 was found to be the most active catalyst for selective oxidation of o-cresol to SAL. Effect of several oxygen sources such as air, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), molecular oxygen (O2), and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was studied for the oxidation of o-cresol. There was a complete conversion of o-cresol with 98% yield of SAL at 5 atm O2 pressure and 80 °C in 2 h. Additionally, the catalysts (virgin as well as reused forms) were characterized by FESEM, EDS, HR-TEM, XRD, CO2-TPD, TPR, Raman Spectra, BET surface area analysis, XPS, and DSC-TGA. The reaction kinetic model was developed using Mars van Krevelen mechanism. The catalyst was found to be inexpensive, robust, active, and showed very good reusability of 4 cycles, which makes it an attractive choice for o-cresol oxidation to SAL. The atom economy of the oxidation process is 98.15%. Thus, this process is an example of the synthesis of a vital chemical entity, salicylaldehyde, at mild reaction condition by a novel clean and green route.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of salicylaldehyde through oxidation of o-cresol: Evaluation of activity and selectivity of different metals supported on OMS-2 nanorods and kinetics
